child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1975. West Papuan Phylum Languages on the Mainland of New Guinea: Bird's Head (Vogelkop) Peninsula. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 717-728. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.geography: spoken in a few coastal villages immediately to the south of the township of Manokwari. It is surrounded by Hattam.

child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1975. West Papuan Phylum Languages on the Mainland of New Guinea: Bird's Head (Vogelkop) Peninsula. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 717-728. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.geography: Spoken in the majority of the Borai-Hattam language area, except in Borai speaking villages

child.pub-comments: "The status of the family as a member of the West Papuan Phylum however will remain uncertain until more data have become availabe, and in view of this, it has, for the time being, been given sub-phyllic status within the phylum" (Voorhoeve 1975:724). At the time of publication, there were no published materials on Borai or Hattam. Total estimated number of speakers: 9000+
child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1975. West Papuan Phylum Languages on the Mainland of New Guinea: Bird's Head (Vogelkop) Peninsula. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 717-728. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.geography: found in the northeast corner of the Bird's Head where it constitutes a deep wedge between the Meax and Mantion languages of the East Bird's Head phylum-level stock

child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1975. West Papuan Phylum Languages on the Mainland of New Guinea: Bird's Head (Vogelkop) Peninsula. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 717-728. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.geography: spoken in the coastal area to the west of Konda

child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1975. West Papuan Phylum Languages on the Mainland of New Guinea: Bird's Head (Vogelkop) Peninsula. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 717-728. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.geography: spoken in the interior north of Konda in at least eight villages

child.pub-comments: The author notes that Kuwani is known through only one word list.
child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1975. West Papuan Phylum Languages on the Mainland of New Guinea: Bird's Head (Vogelkop) Peninsula. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 717-728. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.geography: the exact location of the language is not known, but judging from its vocabulary it should be in south-eastern corner of the family's territory, near the phylum border with Konda

child.pub-comments: "Kuwani shares more than 50% cognates with Kalabra and Tehit; together they form a subgroup within the family" (Voohoeve 1975:718). Node not named by author.
child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1975. West Papuan Phylum Languages on the Mainland of New Guinea: Bird's Head (Vogelkop) Peninsula. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 717-728. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.

child.pub-comments: "It shares 50% cognates with Kalabra, 45% with Kuwani, and 30% with Tehit. Moraid is aberrant in that its cognation percentages with the languages of the south Bird's Head Sub Phylum (Trans-New Guinea Phylum) are generally higher than those of its fellow family-members whereas its cognation percentages with the languages of the Central Bird's Head Family and with Amberbaken are lower" (Voorhoeve 1975:719).
child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1975. West Papuan Phylum Languages on the Mainland of New Guinea: Bird's Head (Vogelkop) Peninsula. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 717-728. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.geography: spoken in the interior east of Moi, and north of Kalabra and Tehit

child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1975. West Papuan Phylum Languages on the Mainland of New Guinea: Bird's Head (Vogelkop) Peninsula. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 717-728. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.geography: spoken in the villages Waliam and Yefbo, on Salawati island

child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1975. West Papuan Phylum Languages on the Mainland of New Guinea: Bird's Head (Vogelkop) Peninsula. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 717-728. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.geography: spoken in Waipu village, on Salawati island

child.pub-comments: "Moi shares between 35-40% cognates with Moraid, Tehit, Kalabra, and Kuwani" (Voorhoeve 1975:719).
child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1975. West Papuan Phylum Languages on the Mainland of New Guinea: Bird's Head (Vogelkop) Peninsula. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 717-728. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.geography: spoken in nearly the whole northwestern half of the family's territory, including the south-eastern side of Salawati island.

child.pub-comments: "It has obviously been influenced by its north-eastern neighbour Moi with which it shares about 50% cognates, whereas the percentages with the other members of the family lie around the family-stock level border (25% with Moraid, 28% with Kuwani, 30% with Tehit, and 34% with Kalabra)" (Voorhoeve 1975:719).
child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1975. West Papuan Phylum Languages on the Mainland of New Guinea: Bird's Head (Vogelkop) Peninsula. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 717-728. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.geography: spoken in the westernmost tip of the Bird's Head

child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1975. West Papuan Phylum Languages on the Mainland of New Guinea: Bird's Head (Vogelkop) Peninsula. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 717-728. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.geography: western part of Bird's Head as well as the the eastern part of the island of Salawati opposite of Bird's Head's western shore

child.pub-comments: "Brat is reported to be spoken in nine dialects (Elmbery 1955)" (Voorhoeve 1975:721). Estimated speakers: 15,000+. For grammatical notes on Brat, see Cowan 1953 and Elmberg 1955. For lexical data about Brat, see Cowan 1957, 1958, 1960, and 1963.
child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1975. West Papuan Phylum Languages on the Mainland of New Guinea: Bird's Head (Vogelkop) Peninsula. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 717-728. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.geography: Brat, with over 15,000 speakers, centres round the Ayamaru Lakes

child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1975. West Papuan Phylum Languages on the Mainland of New Guinea: Bird's Head (Vogelkop) Peninsula. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 717-728. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.geography: spoken by about 5,000 people living in Tamrau Mountains

child.pub-comments: "The two languages [Karon Dori and Brat] are closely related, sharing 80% cognates" (Voorhoeve 1975:721).
child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1975. West Papuan Phylum Languages on the Mainland of New Guinea: Bird's Head (Vogelkop) Peninsula. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 717-728. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.geography: occupies a large area in the interior of the Bird's Head, from the Tamrau mountains in the north to the southern coastal plain

child.pub-comments: The author suggests consulting Cowan (1953) for more information.
child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1975. West Papuan Phylum Languages on the Mainland of New Guinea: Bird's Head (Vogelkop) Peninsula. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 717-728. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.geography: in the interior

child.pub-comments: The author suggests consulting Cowan (1953) for more information.
child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1975. West Papuan Phylum Languages on the Mainland of New Guinea: Bird's Head (Vogelkop) Peninsula. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 717-728. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.geography: along the north coast

child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1975. West Papuan Phylum Languages on the Mainland of New Guinea: Bird's Head (Vogelkop) Peninsula. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 717-728. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.geography: stretches over the western part of the Tamrau mountains in the north Bird's Head, and along a considerable part of the north coast

child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1975. West Papuan Phylum Languages on the Mainland of New Guinea: Bird's Head (Vogelkop) Peninsula. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 717-728. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.

child.pub-comments: "The inter-family cognation percentages, ranging from 12 to 15%, are near the lower limit of stock-level relationships. The West Bird's Head Family has cognation percentages averaging 10% with the other two families" (Voorhoeve 1975:718).
child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1975. West Papuan Phylum Languages on the Mainland of New Guinea: Bird's Head (Vogelkop) Peninsula. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 717-728. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.

child.pub-comments: "Structurally, Amberbaken seems to tie in closely with the languages of the super-stock; on the lexical level however the ties are weak" (Voorhoeve 1975:723).
child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1975. West Papuan Phylum Languages on the Mainland of New Guinea: Bird's Head (Vogelkop) Peninsula. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 717-728. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.geography: in the northwest of the region where the Amberbaken stock is spoken

child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1975. West Papuan Phylum Languages on the Mainland of New Guinea: Bird's Head (Vogelkop) Peninsula. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 717-728. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.geography: in the southeast of the region where the Amberbaken stock is spoken

child.pub-comments: "They [Amberbaken and Kebar] are closely related, perhaps even to the extent that they could be considered dialects of one language, but the only available word list in Kebar is too short to draw firm conclusions" (Voorhoeve 1975:722). Total estimated number of speakers: 5,000+
child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1975. West Papuan Phylum Languages on the Mainland of New Guinea: Bird's Head (Vogelkop) Peninsula. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 717-728. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.geography: occupies the area between the northwestern border of the Central Bird's Head Family and the north coast. In the west it borders on Karon Pantai, in the east on Meax.

root.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1975. West Papuan Phylum Languages on the Mainland of New Guinea: Bird's Head (Vogelkop) Peninsula. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 717-728. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
